title: Alaska’s suicide rate increases for the 4th year in a row

content: Ok cracker, I'll bite. The suicide rate in Alaska has always been high. Two main factors are usually responsible. Main one is 10 months of winter every year and it gets dark for long periods of time. The teen suicide rate is especailly high because of that. Then there is the alcohol that some choose to use to cover up their depression. It happens mostly in the bush but sometimes in Anchortown, Fairbanks and Junuea. It is a sad thing. Not everyone sees Alaska like I do. My favorite place on the planet. You should come visit this beautiful place cracker. Summer is the best time. Sun doesn't go down for a month and a half or so. Maybe it will help ease the obsession you seem to have for Alaska.

content: In the 1960's at Eielson, they sarcastically used to call SAC the "Tragic Air Command" due to the drinking, occasional suicide, divorces, etc. This was before cable TV and all. By our standards, very primitive conditions. A real Peyton Place. The article seemed to address the native Americans who inhabit the place. They're generally a pretty pathetic people, anyway.

content: quote: Originally posted by vsibaby: The article seemed to address the native Americans who inhabit the place. They're generally a pretty pathetic people, anyway. Well, that might be true in Anchorage or Fairbanks. There is a lot of prejudice here against the natives, which really ticks me off. I have seen it first hand and there is no excuse for it. However, in the bush, it isn't just the natives. I have known a quite few people (white) who couldn't handle life here very well. Most of the natives are stronger than the rest of us as long as they do not surrender themselves to the alchohol that claims so many here. I find the constant challenge of survival in the bush to be personally rewarding.

It happens mostly in the bush but sometimes in Anchortown, Fairbanks and Junuea. It is a sad thing. Not everyone sees Alaska like I do. My favorite place on the planet. You should come visit this beautiful place cracker. Summer is the best time. Sun doesn't go down for a month and a half or so. Maybe it will help ease the obsession you seem to have for Alaska. Angel, I agree with you and crackerjacks can't come--apparently he doesn't get a vacation! Also, all the aticle speaks to is the 'rate'! It doesn't speak to the actual numbers so it boils down to limited math skills and another soap box issue! Early in my career, I made 4 deployments to Iceland. Similar weather patterns to Alaska exist there. Long Summers and long depressing Winters. The alcohol rate along with the suicide rate were high--guess when? In the winter! It is rough but here, it is all about survival of the fittest. Some people give up too easily. Cabin fever can be pretty bad for some. But I have learned, life is what you make it and the answer can be as simple as getting up and going outside. It just takes the right winter gear and a head light for your head. I find winter sled dog rides are the best, especially when the moon is full! Never been to Alaska but, I would love to go their some day... I hear that the hunting and fishing is spectacular... I know it may sound goofy but, I watch all the shows that I can about Alaska, especially any to do with hunting, fishing, flying and trucking and wish that I were a young man again, like I said, I guess I'm just an old goofy man, dreaming of adventures... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
reply: You're never too old for Alaska Sunliner. You should come visit. The fish and hunting are spectacular.

content: quote: Originally posted by NickBrand: quote: Originally posted by SUNLINER81: quote: Originally posted by NickBrand: quote: Originally posted by AngelHeart: quote: Originally posted by vsibaby: The article seemed to address the native Americans who inhabit the place. They're generally a pretty pathetic people, anyway. Well, that might be true in Anchorage or Fairbanks. There is a lot of prejudice here against the natives, which really ticks me off. I have seen it first hand and there is no excuse for it. However, in the bush, it isn't just the natives. I have known a quite few people (white) who couldn't handle life here very well. Most of the natives are stronger than the rest of us as long as they do not surrender themselves to the alchohol that claims so many here. I find the constant challenge of survival in the bush to be personally rewarding. I like to take "survival training" in the "bush" at least thrice a week here in Nebraska.... Yes that is sarcasm... or is it!?? The "bad bush"?... LOL Respectfully, SUNLINER81 It's not bad from where I'm sitting....
